title: Neuromuscular Respiratory Failure
scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of respiratory failure from neuromuscular disorders in adults. Covers recognition of impending respiratory failure, monitoring parameters (FVC, NIF), indications for intubation, non-invasive ventilation (NIV) considerations, disease-specific treatments (myasthenia gravis crisis, GBS, ALS, muscular dystrophy, other myopathies), and weaning considerations. Excludes central causes of respiratory failure (brainstem stroke, sedative overdose) and primary pulmonary causes (pneumonia, ARDS, COPD exacerbation).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL**: Assess ventilation (PaCO2) and oxygenation (PaO2); hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45) indicates hypoventilation; respiratory acidosis = severe; PaO2/FiO2 ratio
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal: pH 7.35-7.45, PaCO2 35-45, PaO2 >80; **Hypercapnia with respiratory acidosis = impending/current respiratory failure** — consider intubation

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection (pneumonia as trigger or complication); baseline; anemia (reduces O2 carrying capacity)
Electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca, Phos — all affect muscle function); renal function; glucose
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia can all worsen neuromuscular weakness

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia worsens neuromuscular junction transmission and muscle weakness
Hypophosphatemia causes profound muscle weakness including respiratory muscles
Essential/Core Labs.target: >2.5 mg/dL; replete if low (can cause respiratory failure at <1.0)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypocalcemia increases neuromuscular excitability; hypercalcemia causes weakness
**MG workup**: positive in 85% of generalized MG; 50% of ocular MG; confirms diagnosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive = MG; negative does NOT exclude (check MuSK, LRP4)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: If AChR negative but MG suspected clinically; MuSK-positive MG has distinct features (bulbar predominant, may not respond well to cholinesterase inhibitors)
If both AChR and MuSK negative ("seronegative MG"); less commonly available
Elevated in myopathies, muscular dystrophies; may be normal in MG, GBS, ALS
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal in MG, GBS; elevated in myopathies, rhabdomyolysis; very high (>10,000) in inflammatory myopathies, dystrophies

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction: hyperthyroidism worsens MG; hypothyroidism causes myopathy
Infection as trigger (pneumonia, UTI can precipitate MG crisis); distinguish infection from disease exacerbation
Drugs affecting neuromuscular function; intoxication as mimicker

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Rarely available; assess for cholinergic crisis (too much pyridostigmine vs. myasthenic crisis)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Therapeutic range varies; clinical assessment more reliable

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: GBS workup; GQ1b positive in Miller Fisher syndrome
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive supports GBS diagnosis; negative does NOT exclude

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: GBS: albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein, normal cells — may not be present in first week); exclude infection
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: GBS: protein elevated (>45 mg/dL), WBC <10 (usually <5); may be normal early

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: **MG diagnosis**: decremental response at 3 Hz stimulation (>10% decrement) in proximal muscles
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: >10% decrement = neuromuscular junction defect (MG); no decrement does NOT exclude MG

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: **Most sensitive test for MG** (92-98%); increased jitter and blocking
GBS: demyelinating pattern (prolonged F-waves, conduction block, temporal dispersion) or axonal (reduced amplitudes); ALS: widespread denervation; myopathy: myopathic units
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: GBS: demyelinating or axonal; ALS: diffuse denervation; myopathy: small, polyphasic MUPs

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: **Thymoma screening in MG**: 10-15% of MG patients have thymoma; all MG patients need chest imaging
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Thymoma (anterior mediastinal mass); thymic hyperplasia; normal thymus

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Associated with thymoma in MG; may indicate need for more aggressive thymoma search
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive in older MG patients and thymoma-associated MG

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paraneoplastic neuromuscular syndromes (LEMS with anti-VGCC and small cell lung cancer); myositis with malignancy
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS); associated with SCLC in 50-60%

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Inflammatory myopathy (dermatomyositis, polymyositis); muscular dystrophy; congenital myopathy
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Inflammatory infiltrate; dystrophic changes; structural abnormalities

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Suspected hereditary myopathy/dystrophy; known family history; young patient with progressive weakness
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Specific mutations (dystrophin, FSHD, myotonic dystrophy, etc.)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Myositis-specific antibodies (Jo-1, Mi-2, SRP, MDA5, etc.)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Specific antibodies guide diagnosis and prognosis

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Rarely done now (replaced by serologic testing and SFEMG); bedside MG test; risk of cholinergic crisis; atropine must be at bedside
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Transient improvement = positive (MG); false positives/negatives occur

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Bedside test for ocular MG; apply ice pack to closed eyelid for 2 min; improvement in ptosis suggests MG
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Improvement = positive; negative does NOT exclude

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Upper airway obstruction pattern (variable extrathoracic obstruction in vocal cord weakness); restrictive pattern in neuromuscular disease
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Restrictive pattern; flattened inspiratory loop suggests extrathoracic obstruction

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Sleep-disordered breathing in neuromuscular disease; nocturnal hypoventilation; assess need for nocturnal NIV
Baseline and monitoring in chronic neuromuscular disease; FVC, MIP, MEP, SNIP
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: FVC; supine vs. upright FVC (>20% drop suggests diaphragm weakness)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: GBS diagnosis (albuminocytologic dissociation); may be normal in first week; NOT typically needed for MG diagnosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: GBS: elevated protein (often >100 mg/dL after first week), normal WBC (<10, usually <5); cytoalbuminous dissociation
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Coagulopathy; skin infection at LP site; elevated ICP

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate; assess for aspiration, pneumonia (trigger for crisis), atelectasis, elevated hemidiaphragm
Essential/First-line.target: Aspiration pneumonia; atelectasis (from weak cough); elevated hemidiaphragm (diaphragm weakness); anterior mediastinal mass (thymoma)

Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL: q4-6h in unstable patients; q1-2h if rapidly declining**; most important monitoring parameter
Essential/First-line.target: FVC >20 mL/kg = adequate; FVC <15-20 mL/kg = consider intubation; FVC declining >30% from baseline = concerning
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Patient cooperation required; cannot perform if intubated (use ventilator parameters)

Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL: Assess inspiratory muscle strength**; complement to FVC; easier for fatigued patients
Essential/First-line.target: NIF < -30 cm H2O = adequate; NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O (less negative) = weak, consider intubation

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess cough strength; correlates with ability to clear secretions
Essential/First-line.target: MEP <40 cm H2O = weak cough; aspiration risk

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess ventilation and oxygenation; hypercapnia is late sign
Essential/First-line.target: PaCO2 >45 = hypoventilation; rising PaCO2 is ominous; PaO2 <60 = hypoxemia

Essential/First-line.timing: Arrhythmia from autonomic dysfunction (GBS); cardiac involvement in muscular dystrophies; baseline for IVIG/PLEX

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h for MG; thymoma screening; all newly diagnosed generalized MG
If CT contraindicated or additional characterization needed
Cardiomyopathy screening in muscular dystrophies (DMD, BMD, LGMD2I, myotonic dystrophy); autonomic dysfunction in GBS; baseline before IVIG
Extended.target: Cardiomyopathy; reduced EF; conduction abnormalities (perform ECG first)

Extended.timing: Assess diaphragm excursion and thickness; non-invasive diaphragm function assessment; bedside
Extended.target: Reduced diaphragm excursion (<1.5 cm during tidal breathing, <4 cm during deep breath); paradoxical motion = diaphragm paralysis

Extended.timing: If pulmonary embolism suspected (immobile patients at high VTE risk)
If LEMS diagnosed to search for underlying malignancy (SCLC in 50-60%)

Rare/Advanced.timing: Assess phrenic nerve function; bilateral phrenic neuropathy as cause of respiratory failure
Rare/Advanced.target: Absent or reduced phrenic CMAP = phrenic neuropathy; prolonged latency

Rare/Advanced.timing: Diaphragm function; "sniff test" — paradoxical upward diaphragm motion with sniff = paralysis
Gold standard for diaphragm strength; requires esophageal and gastric balloon catheters; specialized centers
Nocturnal hypoventilation assessment; sleep-disordered breathing; guide NIV
Rare/Advanced.target: Nocturnal hypoventilation (elevated PtcCO2); desaturations; REM-related events

dosing.instructions: **"20/30/40 Rule":** FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF > -30 cm H2O (less negative), MEP <40 cm H2O = HIGH RISK for respiratory failure; monitor q2-4h (or more frequently if declining); **INTUBATION THRESHOLD:** FVC <15-20 mL/kg, NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O, rising PaCO2, or clinical distress

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: NMD respiratory failure is often predictable by serial FVC/NIF; intubate BEFORE crisis (controlled intubation is safer); ABG abnormalities are LATE signs

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** FVC <15-20 mL/kg (or <1 L); NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O; PaCO2 rising or >50; clinical respiratory distress; inability to clear secretions; aspiration; fatigue; **RSI considerations:** AVOID succinylcholine in myopathies/muscular dystrophy (hyperkalemia), MG (resistance); use rocuronium (may need reduced dose in MG); can use sugammadex for reversal

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Elective intubation is safer than emergent; neuromuscular patients are difficult to bag-mask ventilate; have difficult airway equipment ready; avoid neuromuscular blockers post-intubation if possible

dosing.instructions: **ROLE IS LIMITED IN ACUTE NMD RESPIRATORY FAILURE**; may be considered as bridge in: stable patients with nocturnal hypoventilation, mild hypercapnia without distress, secretion clearance ability preserved, no aspiration risk, patient can protect airway; **AVOID NIV if:** Bulbar dysfunction (aspiration risk), unable to clear secretions, severe hypercapnia (PaCO2 >60), acidosis, rapid decline, altered mental status

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: NIV (BiPAP) has lower threshold for failure in neuromuscular disease than COPD/CHF; bulbar weakness increases aspiration risk; low threshold for intubation; useful for chronic nocturnal hypoventilation

dosing.instructions: **Use CAUTIOUSLY**: Oxygen can mask hypoventilation (hypercapnia develops before desaturation); may eliminate hypoxic drive (though less relevant in NMD than COPD); titrate to SpO2 92-96%; **If hypoxemic + hypercapnic:** This indicates severe failure — intubate, do NOT rely on oxygen alone

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Hypoxemia is a late finding in pure neuromuscular hypoventilation; if hypoxemic, consider aspiration, atelectasis, or imminent failure

dosing.instructions: Weak cough = poor secretion clearance; **Techniques:** Assisted cough (abdominal thrust during cough); mechanical insufflation-exsufflation (CoughAssist) — pressures +40/-40 cm H2O; aggressive pulmonary toilet; chest physiotherapy; suction PRN; **If unable to clear secretions:** Intubate

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Aspiration pneumonia is leading cause of death in chronic NMD; weak cough (MEP <40) = high risk; mechanical cough assist is underutilized and highly effective

dosing.instructions: **MG crisis precipitants (AVOID):** Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tobramycin), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin — less risky but still caution), macrolides (azithromycin, erythromycin), beta-blockers, magnesium (IV), neuromuscular blockers, D-penicillamine, interferon-alpha, checkpoint inhibitors (nivolumab, pembrolizumab); **Full list in Appendix**

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Many medications can worsen neuromuscular transmission; careful medication review essential; see comprehensive list in appendix

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis (enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily) once stable; immobile patients at very high VTE risk

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: High VTE risk in paralyzed/weak patients; balance with IVIG timing (hold anticoagulation during IVIG infusion in some protocols)

dosing.instructions: HOB elevated 30-45°; NPO if significant bulbar weakness; speech-language pathology evaluation; modified diet or enteral feeding if prolonged weakness

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Aspiration pneumonia is major complication; bulbar weakness (dysphagia, weak cough, voice changes) = high risk

dosing.instructions: **First-line for MG crisis (with PLEX):** 2 g/kg total divided over 2-5 days (400 mg/kg/day x 5 days OR 1 g/kg/day x 2 days); **Onset:** 2-5 days; **Duration:** 3-6 weeks; **Pre-treatment:** Check IgA (IgA deficiency = anaphylaxis risk); renal function; volume status

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Efficacy equivalent to PLEX (RCTs); easier logistics than PLEX; side effects: headache (aseptic meningitis), renal failure (sucrose-containing products), thrombosis, hemolysis; slower onset than PLEX

dosing.instructions: **First-line for MG crisis (with IVIG):** 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days (1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; typically 3-4 L); **Onset:** Faster than IVIG (improvement may begin after 2-3 exchanges); requires large-bore central venous access; **Caution:** Hypotension, citrate toxicity (hypocalcemia), infection

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: May work faster than IVIG; useful if rapid response needed; RCT showed PLEX and IVIG equivalent in MG exacerbation; PLEX preferred if IVIG contraindicated (IgA deficiency, renal failure)

dosing.instructions: **In intubated MG crisis patients:** STOP pyridostigmine while intubated; excessive secretions worsen pulmonary toilet; cannot distinguish myasthenic from cholinergic crisis if on pyridostigmine; **Resume cautiously when extubation nearing**

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Pyridostigmine increases secretions; in intubated patient, secretions worsen; hold until preparing for extubation; some restart at lower dose (30 mg q6h) and titrate

dosing.instructions: **CAUTION: Steroids can cause TRANSIENT WORSENING in MG (up to 50% of patients)**; **In crisis:** Start AFTER IVIG/PLEX initiated and patient stabilizing (days 3-5 or later); do NOT start steroids as initial therapy in crisis; **Protocol:** Prednisone 10-20 mg daily, increase by 10 mg every 3-5 days to 1 mg/kg/day (max 60-80 mg); OR IV methylprednisolone 1g daily x 3-5 days then oral

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Steroids are maintenance therapy but can worsen MG acutely ("steroid dip"); always start with IVIG or PLEX first in crisis; steroid-sparing agents (azathioprine, mycophenolate) for long-term

dosing.instructions: **Infection:** Most common trigger; treat aggressively but AVOID contraindicated antibiotics (see list); **Medication-induced:** Stop offending drug; **Surgery/anesthesia:** Stress can trigger crisis; **Tapering immunosuppression:** Restart or increase

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: 30-40% of MG crises have identifiable trigger; treating trigger may hasten recovery

dosing.instructions: **First-line for GBS:** 2 g/kg total over 5 days (400 mg/kg/day x 5 days); start within 2-4 weeks of symptom onset for best efficacy; **Efficacy:** Equivalent to PLEX; faster recovery; fewer complications; **Onset:** Days to 1-2 weeks

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: RCTs show IVIG = PLEX; IVIG preferred due to availability and easier administration; start as soon as diagnosis confirmed (or highly likely); do NOT delay for CSF/EMG confirmation

dosing.instructions: **Alternative to IVIG:** 5 exchanges over 1-2 weeks (200-250 mL/kg total); start within 2-4 weeks of onset; **Consider PLEX if:** IVIG contraindicated; IVIG failure; severe/refractory

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: PLEX and IVIG equivalent; do NOT combine (no added benefit, more complications); PLEX if renal failure (IVIG risk)

dosing.instructions: **Do NOT use steroids for GBS**; no benefit; may cause harm

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Multiple RCTs: steroids do NOT improve GBS outcomes; may delay recovery

dosing.instructions: **GBS has significant autonomic dysfunction (up to 70%):** Cardiac monitoring (arrhythmias, heart block); BP monitoring (labile — hypertension and hypotension); ileus; urinary retention; treat arrhythmias; short-acting antihypertensives (avoid long-acting due to swings); pacing if bradycardia

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Autonomic death is second leading cause of GBS mortality after respiratory failure; close cardiac monitoring; avoid medications that worsen autonomic dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Pain in GBS is common (60-90%) and often severe; neuropathic pain; back pain; radicular pain; **Treatment:** Gabapentin 300 mg TID → titrate; pregabalin; opioids PRN; AVOID NSAIDs if renal concerns

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Pain can be as debilitating as weakness; multimodal approach; gabapentinoids first-line

dosing.instructions: **CRITICAL:** ALS is progressive and fatal; respiratory failure is end-stage; discuss intubation, tracheostomy, long-term mechanical ventilation BEFORE crisis; many ALS patients choose comfort care / no intubation; **Advance directive** should be documented

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Intubation in ALS often leads to chronic ventilator dependence (cannot wean); tracheostomy and home ventilation is option for some but significantly impacts QoL; respect patient autonomy

dosing.instructions: **Standard of care for ALS respiratory insufficiency:** Start NIV when FVC <50% predicted or symptoms of nocturnal hypoventilation; prolongs survival (median 7-11 months) and improves QoL; **Settings:** BiPAP S/T mode; IPAP 10-20, EPAP 4-6; titrate to comfort; initially nocturnal → extended daytime use as disease progresses

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Cochrane review: NIV improves survival and QoL in ALS (especially with limb-onset); bulbar patients benefit less but still benefit; no evidence for invasive ventilation superiority over NIV with experienced teams

dosing.instructions: All ALS patients with weak cough (PCF <270 L/min or MEP <60); reduces respiratory infections; can be used with NIV; **Settings:** +40/-40 cm H2O; 4-5 cycles; several times daily

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Improves secretion clearance; reduces pneumonia; can prolong NIV effectiveness; underutilized

dosing.instructions: 50 mg PO BID; modestly prolongs survival (~2-3 months); neuroprotective; continue unless intolerant

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Only FDA-approved disease-modifying drug for ALS with survival benefit (though modest); continue through respiratory failure unless goals of care dictate otherwise

doseOptions.text: 60 mg daily x14 days then off 14 days
doseOptions.orderSentence: Edaravone 60 mg IV daily x14 days then off 14 days

dosing.instructions: IV infusion or oral formulation; may slow functional decline; expensive; used in early ALS
dosing.orderSentence: Edaravone 60 mg IV daily x14 days then off 14 days

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Recent approval; modest benefit in selected patients; often continued if started

dosing.instructions: Sialorrhea (glycopyrrolate, atropine drops, botulinum toxin to salivary glands); thick secretions (guaifenesin, N-acetylcysteine, hydration); pseudobulbar affect (dextromethorphan/quinidine); spasticity (baclofen, tizanidine); pain; depression

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Palliative symptom management is cornerstone of ALS care; multidisciplinary team essential

dosing.instructions: If patient declines intubation or chronic mechanical ventilation; opioids for dyspnea (morphine 2-5 mg IV/SQ q2-4h PRN — does NOT hasten death and relieves suffering); anxiolytics (lorazepam); comfort measures; hospice referral

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Dyspnea is the most distressing symptom at end of life; opioids are safe and effective; do not withhold for fear of "hastening death"

dosing.instructions: **Inflammatory myopathy:** Corticosteroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) + steroid-sparing agent (methotrexate, azathioprine, IVIG for dermatomyositis); **Hypothyroid myopathy:** Thyroid replacement; **Drug-induced myopathy (statins):** Stop drug; **Metabolic myopathy:** Specific treatment (enzyme replacement for Pompe disease)

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Many myopathies are treatable; identify and treat cause; inflammatory myopathies are steroid-responsive

dosing.instructions: Chronic respiratory insufficiency in muscular dystrophy (DMD, BMD, LGMD, myotonic dystrophy); start when FVC <50%, symptoms, or nocturnal hypoventilation on PSG; prolongs survival in DMD

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: NIV is standard of care for chronic respiratory failure in MD; delays tracheostomy; improves survival and QoL

dosing.instructions: Same as ALS; weak cough universal in advanced MD; prevents pneumonia

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Critical for preventing respiratory infections

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Cardiac monitoring (DMD, BMD, LGMD2I, myotonic DM)** N/A -

dosing.instructions: Cardiomyopathy is common and can cause death; annual echocardiogram; ACE inhibitors / beta-blockers for cardiomyopathy; antiarrhythmics / pacemaker / ICD as indicated
dosing.orderSentence: **Cardiac monitoring (DMD, BMD, LGMD2I, myotonic DM)** N/A -

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Cardiac disease is leading cause of death in some muscular dystrophies; proactive cardiac management essential

dosing.instructions: **Absolute contraindication in muscular dystrophy and most myopathies**: Hyperkalemic cardiac arrest; use rocuronium (with sugammadex available for reversal)

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Succinylcholine causes massive K+ release from dystrophic muscle; fatal hyperkalemia

dosing.instructions: **Mode:** Volume-controlled (AC/VC) or Pressure-support (PS) during weaning; **Tidal volume:** 6-8 mL/kg IBW (lung-protective); **Rate:** 12-16 to achieve adequate minute ventilation; **PEEP:** 5 (higher if atelectasis or hypoxemia); **FiO2:** Titrate to SpO2 92-96%; **I:E ratio:** 1:2 or 1:3; avoid breath-stacking

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: NMD patients generally have healthy lungs; lung-protective ventilation still applies; goal is to support ventilation while disease-specific treatment works

dosing.instructions: **NMD weaning is often prolonged:** Disease-specific treatment must take effect (MG: IVIG/PLEX effect in 3-7 days; GBS: weeks); **Weaning trial criteria:** FVC >15 mL/kg; NIF < -25 cm H2O; adequate cough; secretions manageable; underlying disease improving; **SBT (spontaneous breathing trial):** T-piece or low PS (5-8 cm H2O) x 30-120 min; assess for fatigue, tachypnea, hypercapnia

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Premature extubation leads to re-intubation; NMD patients may need longer ventilation than other ICU patients; patience; daily SBT when criteria met

dosing.instructions: Pass SBT; FVC >15-20 mL/kg AND improving trajectory; NIF < -25 to -30 cm H2O; effective cough (able to clear secretions); alert and cooperative; bulbar function adequate (can swallow); no heavy sedation; consider cuff leak test

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Higher threshold for extubation in NMD than general ICU patients; failed extubation is dangerous

dosing.instructions: **Consider if:** Unable to wean after 2-3 weeks of optimal disease-specific treatment; ALS with decision for long-term ventilation; severe GBS; **Timing:** No firm consensus; typically discuss at 10-14 days if no progress; earlier in conditions with known prolonged course

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Tracheostomy allows for weaning, reduces sedation needs, allows speech (with speaking valve), but has complications and care burden; goals of care discussion essential

dosing.instructions: Close monitoring for 24-48h; serial FVC/NIF; watch for fatigue, stridor; have reintubation equipment ready; consider prophylactic NIV post-extubation in borderline cases

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Re-intubation rates higher in NMD; close monitoring; low threshold for NIV support post-extubation

Succinylcholine: hyperkalemia in myopathies; all NMBs: prolonged weakness in MG
Medications to AVOID in Neuromuscular Di.safer alternative: Avoid if possible; if needed: rocuronium (reduced dose in MG) + sugammadex

Medications to AVOID in Neuromuscular Di.risk: Can trigger or worsen MG, myositis, GBS-like syndromes
Can cause myopathy; worsen pre-existing myopathy
Can cause transient worsening of MG ("steroid dip")
Medications to AVOID in Neuromuscular Di.safer alternative: Start AFTER IVIG/PLEX in MG crisis

Stable but requires monitoring q4-6h; improving trajectory; stable on NIV; post-extubation observation
Stable respiratory function; FVC >30 mL/kg and stable; for diagnostic workup of mild exacerbation; initiation of immunotherapy without respiratory compromise
FVC >25-30 mL/kg and stable/improving; off supplemental O2 or at baseline; able to clear secretions

disposition.disposition: Off mechanical ventilation (or stable on chronic NIV)
disposition.criteria: Extubated and stable x 24-48h; or established on home NIV with stable settings
IVIG/PLEX completed; oral immunosuppression started (MG); able to continue treatment outpatient
Tolerating oral diet or enteral feeding established; swallowing safe per SLP
PT/OT clearance; able to perform ADLs or adequate support
Neurology (1-2 weeks); pulmonology (if chronic respiratory issues); PCP; cardiology (if applicable)
Disease education; medication instructions; when to return to ED (worsening weakness, dyspnea, dysphagia); MedicAlert bracelet for MG; medication list (avoid contraindicated drugs)
CoughAssist, suction machine, NIV (if prescribed); home nursing if tracheostomy/ventilator
